instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LCD_BKLT_PWM: What is LCD_BKLT_PWM? LCD_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
hi,

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight . i tried different screen but same  problem

L9000 = 3,3 voltage
j9000 pin 40 = 25 voltage
<RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> = No voltage 

<CHIP>U9600</CHIP> Could the problem be with the <CHIP>U9600</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
"j9000 pin 40 = 25 voltage
<RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> = No voltage"
Steady 25V?
Really strange to get voltage there, without <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> present.

Do you get image on internal LCD?
External video is OK?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: I have one of these.   25v on pin 40.   Trying to figure it out.   Tried a test screen.  Still no back light.  Has image

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
I think 15" LCD requires higher voltage.
Just in case, compare with working machine.

Tried changing <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>?
